The **CDKN2A** gene encodes a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor that plays a critical role in cell cycle regulation and tumor suppression. Mutations in CDKN2A are strongly associated with **melanoma**, as well as other cancers like pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors and some sporadic tumors. These mutations disrupt the normal function of p16, a key regulator of the G1/S checkpoint, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation. In the given pathway, CDKN2A inhibits CDK4/6, which otherwise activate RB1. Loss of CDKN2A function allows CDK4/6 to phosphorylate RB1, releasing E2F to drive the cell cycle, contributing to tumorigenesis. Thus, CDKN2A mutations drive oncogenesis by compromising G1 checkpoint control.

\boxed{Melanoma}

This pathway involves amyloid beta (Abeta) production from APP, which leads to activation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (mAChR), triggering downstream signaling through GNAQ, PLCB, IP3, and ITPR, resulting in increased intracellular calcium. The NAGS allele is associated with **Propionic Acidemia**. This autosomal recessive disorder results from defects in the NAGS gene, which encodes N-acetylglutamate synthase, a critical enzyme in the urea cycle. NAGS is required to produce N-acetylglutamate, an essential activator of carbamoyl-phosphate synthase 1 (CPS1), the rate-limiting enzyme in the urea cycle. Deficiency in NAGS leads to impaired ammonia detoxification, causing hyperammonemia, metabolic acidosis, and neurologic damage. Symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, seizures, and developmental delay. Early diagnosis and dietary management are crucial for disease mitigation.  
\boxed{Propionic Acidemia}
